summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas today entered a final judgment against United Healthcare Services, Inc. and United Healthcare of Louisiana, Inc., which are charged with violations of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Metairie, Louisiana, alleges that United Healthcare violated the antifraud provisions of Section 502(a)(3) of the ERISA provisions of the federal securities laws.  According to the complaint, United Healthcare failed to adequately explain to the court that it was entitled to a full and fair review of its claims under ERISA.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the company failed to provide timely and accurate information about certain of the issues raised in the complaint.  United Healthcare's complaint also alleges that, in violation of Rule 12(b)(5) of ERISA, it failed to comply with certain of its obligations under the federal reporting provisions.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, United has consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins it from violating these provisions and orders it to pay a civil penalty equal to the amount of its disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.   The settlement is subject to court approval. Â The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them investments using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can quickly and easily check the backgrounds of people selling investments by using theÂ SEC's investor.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.Â In a parallel action, the U.K. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against the defendants.  On October 20, 2017, the SEC filed a First Amended and Restated Complaint (hereinafter "First Amended Complaint") against UHC Insurance Company (the "Insurance Company") alleging that UHC violated the anti-assignment provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction against future violations of these provisions, as well as an order requiring the payment of civil penalties, and a court order prohibiting the defendants from participating in any offering of or selling any investment in the securities of any insurance company, employee benefit trusts, self-insured plans, or other entities that are obligated to pay for services rendered by a member of a healthcare plan.
